message.content: This question requires knowledge about the properties of a highly polished surface. A highly polished surface reflects light, redirecting the light energy that hits it. This is why highly polished surfaces appear shiny. Option (A) is incorrect because an absorbent material would not have a highly polished surface. Option (C) is incorrect because shadows are formed when light is blocked by an object, not attracted to it. Option (D) is incorrect because shattering is not a property of a highly polished surface, but rather a result of extreme force or pressure.

This question requires basic knowledge about the interaction between light and polished surfaces. When a surface is highly polished, it becomes very smooth and reflects light in a predictable manner. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) redirect light energy. Option (A) is incorrect because a highly polished surface reflects, rather than absorbs, light energy. Option (C) is incorrect because, while shadows may be visible on a highly polished surface, the surface itself does not attract shadows. Option (D) is incorrect because a highly polished surface does not shatter, as it is not related to the physical properties of the material.

This question requires knowledge about the properties of highly polished surfaces. A highly polished surface reflects light very well and therefore redirects the light energy that falls onto it. Option (A) is incorrect because absorption of light energy is more likely to occur on rough or matte surfaces. Option (C) is unrelated to the behavior of light on a highly polished surface. Option (D) is unrelated because a highly polished surface does not have a tendency to shatter.

Option (A) is incorrect because a polished surface will reflect, not absorb, light energy. Option (C) is incorrect because shadows are caused by the absence of light and are not attracted to surfaces. Option (D) is incorrect because a highly polished surface does not necessarily mean it will shatter.

This is because a polished surface has a smooth and flat surface that allows light to bounce off at equal angles of incidence and reflection. Option (A) is incorrect because if the surface was absorbing light energy, it would appear dark. Option (C) is incorrect because the polished surface does not attract shadows, it simply reflects light. Option (D) is unrelated to the behavior of light on a highly polished surface.
